bibl.title: John Matthews v. Henry M. White. Complaint
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
United States District Court for the Western District of Washington In the matter of the application of John Matthews } No. 6203 for a writ of Habeas Corpus } COMPLAINT
Comes now the above named petitioner by George F. Vanderveer, his attorney, and alleges as follows:

I. That at all the times hereinafter mentioned Henry M. White was United States Commisioner of Immigration for the District of Washington, having his headquarters in the city of Seattle, State of Washington.

II. That at all the times hereinafter mentioned your petitioner was and still is a citizen of Ukrainia and that more than thirteen years ago he emigrated from Ukrainia to the Dominion of Canada, thence to the United States of America, where in the year 1920 he was convicted of a violation of the United States postal law relating to the mailing of obscene pictures and was sentenced to imprisonment in the United States penintentiary at McNeil's Island.

III. That thereafter, and in consequence of your petitioner's conviction as aforessaid, the United States of America, acting by its Secretary of Labor, instituted proceedings against your petitioner to secure his deportation from the United States Immigration statutes and on the 19th day of February, 1921, after a due hearing it was determined by said Secretary of Labor for the United States that your petitioner had been born in and was a citizen of Ukrania aforesaid and should be deported thence under the provisions of the immigration statutes above referred to.

That ever since said date your petitioner has been and still is unlawfully and unreasonably restained of his liberty in the County jail of King County by Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration aforesaid, under the pretended authority of said warrant or order of deportation and that said restraint is unreasonable and unlawful in this: that the government of the United States, as your deponent is informed and believes, has no diplomatic relations with the government of Ukrania and is unable to deport your petitioner to said Ukrania and is making no attempt to do so and has no intention of so doing, and that unless the said Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration aforesaid, is prevented from so doing he will continue unlafully and unreasonably to retain your petitioner of his liberty and confine him as a prisoner in the County jail of King County aforesaid, all in violation of your petitioner's right under the Constitution and laws of the United States.

WHEREFORE your petitioner prays an order directing the Clerk of this Court to issue under its seal a writ of habeas corpus directed at Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, requiring him to produce the body of your petitioner in the above entitled court at such time as the Court may fix and then and there show cause, if any he has, why your petitioner should be further restrained of his liberty.
John Matthews Petitioner
G Vanderveer Attorney for Petitioner
405 Collins Building, Seattle, Wash.
STATE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY OF KING } ss.

John Matthews, being first duly sworn on oath deposes and says: that he is the petitioner in the above entitled faction; that he has read the foregoing complaint, knows the contents thereof and that the same is true as he verily believes.
John Matthews
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 5th day of August, 1921.
Lalla Rogers Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT EASTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF JOHN MATTHEWS FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
COMPLAINT
George F. Vanderveer Atty for Petitioner
FILED IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT Western District of Washington Northen Division
F.M. Harshberger, Clerk By S.E. Leitch Deputy
